doc.after: The nature of the murders and of the victims drew attention to the poor living conditions in the East End,[126] and galvanised public opinion against the overcrowded, unsanitary slums.[127] In the two decades after the murders, the worst of the slums were cleared and demolished,[128] but the streets and some buildings survive and the legend of the Ripper is still promoted by guided tours of the murder sites.[129] The Ten Bells public house in Commercial Street was frequented by at least one of the victims and was the focus of such tours for many years.[130]
